description:
Based on the game show of the same name hosted by Gene Rayburn, which ran on NBC from 1958-60.

The game was played similarly to Name That Tune, but with only the first three notes of a popular song being played, and players then bid on their ability to guess the song correctly. The game cost more than the typical board game for the era due to including a small, eight-note xylophone which players used to begin each song.

How's this supposed to work again? What happens when a team of two explainers are supposed to describe a concept but can only say the sentences together? But it gets better: the players can't discuss what they want to say ahead of time and must build the sentence while alternating words! A good time is guaranteed because the rest all try to figure out what the concept is at the same time. Who will have the most points?

This set of Team Work "Fußball 1" covers the topic soccer.

Expands:

    Team Work Original

'Explore Europe' (aka Europareise} meets 'Malefiz' - two (almost) classic German games combined to form an Asterix travel game across Europe. 
Players have to visit 5 locations before they can pick up Caesar’s laurels in Rome. Before they can deliver them to their village they have to visit another 5 locations. Blocking pieces simulate the 'evil Romans'.

Each player tries to collect all the pieces needed to build his goal machine (hidden from others) while avoiding pieces that will stop their machine from working. You can add pieces to your machine from your warehouse, try to steal the pieces from your opponents, or use one of the special cards.

2-6 players start with 18.500 gaming money and when the first player goes bankrupt, the game ends and the player with the most money wins the game.

Included in this game is 1 color-die and 6 dice in the colors shown on the color-die. There is also a paying board, which shows numbers from 4-20 and the corresponding payout amount.

Each turn consists of several dice throws, done by the "active" player. The inactive players can place fix bets (of 100) before each dice throw and all winning amounts are to be paid by the active player!

The dice throws are done by using the following procedure: the dice with the color showing on the color-die is placed on the paying board and it's number is added to the numbers of the dice already there.

Before the active player goes on throwing the remaining dice, the other players can retire and let them give the won amount from the active player. Fortunately, the active has also a winning option: when the color-die shows a color of a die already on the paying board, his turn end immediately and he collects all bets from the other players.

From the packaging text:

"Twist & Hold 'Em Poker Cube features an entire deck of cards on one cube. Your 'hand' is the side that's facing you and the cards are 'shuffled' by turning the rows cube-style. Take anywhere for fun for the whole family!"

Pressman #1493 is basically a Rubik-style cube with stickers having playing card denominations on the faces. Also included are two six-sided dice. One of the dice lists a series of rotation instructions, and the other is the usual pip layout. Both dice have faces in six different colors that correspond to the centers of each face on the main card cube. The values of the central cube spaces increase by twos from 2 to Q (12) and progress through all four suits (hearts & spades are represented twice). The edge pieces are always two cards with a numerical difference of two and are always different in color. Similarly, the corner pieces progress in increments of two, half of them clockwise and half counterclockwise, and always two black and one red or two red and one black, with like colors never in matching suits. Rules for playing variants of Texas Hold 'Em, Black Jack, Vegas, Spades, Chicago Hi/Lo and Rummy are provided, but others could probably be adapted.

Mr. Potato Head played Cootie style.  Each player selects a plastic head (potato, cucumber, orange or carrot), then spins the large spinner to determine what (if any) piece is added to their character.

Mid-sixties Marvin Glass offering from Schaper for two players only.

The modular 'board' consists of a high quality hollow green plastic beanstalk about 18" high with a fluffy white cloud surrounding the top, concealing the 'sleeping' giant.  A sequence of ten small holes spirals from bottom to top of the beanstalk on each side.  Each of the holes is one of three shapes and these accommodate the stems of the plastic leaves players must insert in the correct sequence from bottom to top.

To start the game, all beanstalk leaves are placed inside the hollow beanstalk through a slot situated on each side.  There is a sliding apparatus at the base of the beanstalk which allows each player access to a single leaf on their turn.

The plastic beanstalk leaves come in 3 colors - green, gold & black.  The green leaves have stems that will only fit into specific beanstalk holes and must be replaced inside the beanstalk if they do not match the next in the sequence.  Gold leaves are universal and fit into any beanstalk hole.  Black leaves are useless and are immediately replaced through a slot.

The first player to complete the sequence of leaves in order wins the game.  When a leaf is placed in the final hole at the top of the beanstalk, a spring mechanism is triggered which causes the 'sleeping' giant to pop up.

Season Harvest is a resource-gathering game played on a modular board made of cards.  There are four card types: summer, fall, winter, and spring.  As you play cards to change the seasons in spaces on the board, seeds grow into trees which eventually bear fruit.  Your goal is to harvest as much fruit as possible and end the game with the most fruit in your basket.

Although the basic game is competitive, Season Harvest also has several cooperative variants.

http://www.invisible-city.com/play/292/season-harvest

From the website:

TOTAL PLAY FOOTBALL™ is a card game designed for non-stop action. Players able to recognize different Offensive card plays and make Defensive counter plays will certainly have the advantage. There is no turn for play in the Total Play Football Card Game. Any player can make a play for points or deny points at any time which adds even more fun and excitement to the game. For the love of the game called football and the advent of new technology, football can be played a myriad of ways. No one will feel excluded from playing Total Play Football™ because the game terminology does not require football lingo. All you need is the desire to win at an appealing and entertaining card game that is loads of fun for the whole family. The only way for you to know how well you will embrace the Total Play Football™ card game is to play it.

KootiKooti is an addictive, strategic interactive game that is played with 2.5” flexible rubber game pieces. Using a finger to nudge or flip their KootiKooti, 2 to 4 players take turns, using their skill and judgment to try and ‘pin down’ their opponents KootiKooti to win the round.

Series 1 comprises 50 unique designed colorful game pieces for kids to collect and trade.

From the insert:

The object of this game is to be the first player to land on each of the six blue Safe Driver Stars by exact roll of 1 or 2 dice while traveling clockwise around the gameboard. Player draws the Safe Driver Card from the deck on gameboard which matches the Safe Driver Star on which he has landed. First player to reach HOME with all six different Safe Driver Cards wins the game.

Parts list: 1 gameboard and box with rules platform and plastic tray; 14 Violation cards; 4 AAA Membership cards; 4 sets of 6 Safe Driver Cards; 2 dice; 4 playing pieces; 1 returnable market research card; and approximately $850 play money.

- - - - - - - -

The market research card (return address: Interstate Games, 35 Morrison St. Manchester, NH 03104) asks if you enjoyed playing the game, found the directions easy to follow; learned more about AAA services, etc. It also asks how many times you played it and with what ages of players (10-15, 15-20, 20-50, and over 50). Box says for ages 8-80.

Anyway, I wonder how many surveys were returned to them.

This game was available solely through the magazine "Essen & Trinken" (a magazine for cooking). 
You objective is it to get as many menus as possible. The menu always consist of 4 courses. You collect by drawing a card from a course of your choice. The card shows the kind of menu (classic, veg. etc.)and the value of that dish. You move forward as many spots as the value of the cards - depending on the place you finish you might have to answer a question or you can trade cards with other players.
At the end only finished menus are counted (and all menue cards have to be from the same kind).

All menu-cards contain a real recipe from the magazine, so you can actually use this game as a cook book (if you can understand German)

All change is a tile placement word game that uses a turntable with 4 word slots. Players must place letters into the slot in front of them to make a 3 or 4 letter word.

The turntable is then rotated to present the players with one of the other words, one that their opponents have been working on, which they must add to, change or remove tiles from to make a new word.

Help your 3 little ants find their way to their nest. Avoid the holes near the path where you can hide (get out of the game) from your enemies, which are mixed with good characters in some memory cards. So you have a good chance to stay on the right path.
A game which comes with rules in 8 languages (D,USA,F,E,P,J,NL,I)
This is a game where you try to get a suitable place in heaven via roll and move.  The pieces are wooden angel meeples and there are tokens you collect to put you in a particular choir placement.

From the Amigo rules:

The players collect cards by winning tricks, and these cards are sorted in a special way. The players divide cards into piles by color during the course of the game, and only the point value of the topmost card in each pile counts at the end of the round. The goal of the game is to score as many points as possible.

A note about game play: The deck includes five suits, but players don't need to follow suit during play. Instead suits are important because you have five scoring opportunities each round. The game lasts as many rounds as there are players.

(The English name of this game would be "Null & Void.")

Aim of the game from the rulebook:

The goal of the game is to build the most successful Underground lines and in doing so gain the most points.  You can gain points by connecting your lines to various destinations on the board, and by having the passenger use your lines to travel from station to station.

The player who has best balanced the demands by the time that the deck of destinations is exhausted will be declared the winner.

Gameplay overview:

In On the Underground, the players represent companies building underground lines in London. Each player controls 2-4 different lines (based on the number of players).

On each turn, a player can build four pieces of track on the map in any of their color. All track pieces must extend the color. Alternatively, a player may decide to use two branch tokens (acquired by extending lines to the terminus stations or skipping building turns) to branch out of the line.

During the track building part, the active player can score in four different ways:

     Connect their line to a station with a National Rail symbol (1p)
     Connect their line to a terminus station (2p + a branch token)
     Connect two connection tokens of the same type (3p)
     Building a circular line (1p for each station "inside" the line)


After each turn, the passenger moves to one or two of the four face up destination cards; first to one express destination and then to a regular destination. If there are no cards face up in either type, the passenger only moves once. The passenger always uses the shortest route from their current position, avoiding walking and line changes. The passenger scores one point for each line they used to get to their destination.

When there is not enough destination cards to turn face up from the deck, the passenger marker is removed from the game. Players get equal turns, but after the passenger marker is removed, no more points are awarded from passenger movement and players can only build track. The player with the highest amount of points wins.

A family dinner is arranged and you are one of the members: however, this family has trust issues, and no one's certain who will spoil the pot! Dinner is served in this game of bluffing, cruelty and fun.

From front cover:

"A Beautiful Game of Skill, Strategy, and Maneuvers"

From back cover:

Maneuvering is the new easy to learn game.  It is an action packed board game which combines skill, chance, and special maneuvers to determine a winner.  It incorporates an entirely new concept which is sophisticated and considerably more attractive than conventional board games. (i.e., chess or backgammon).  The game is played on a 15 1/2" x 15 1/2" Maneuvering board where each player has twenty-four ships to protect and defend.  To start the game, these ships are positioned in the first three rows of the board (as shown).  For each turn, the player rolls two dice.  He then moves 2 ships, one for each die the number of spaces indicated by both dice.  The object of the game is to capture all of your opponent's ships or to win by trapping your opponent's ship(s).  The first player to complete one of the game objectives is the winner!

This is the original Uno Card game with three new ways to play.  Mattel had a contest to see what "House Rules" people used and added the three best variations.  The Variants are as follows.

     Jump-In Uno:  In this variation a player can assume control of the game if they have the exact same card that is on top of the discard pile.  (This was the first place winner submited by Wess Eslinger.)
     Seven-O Uno:  This involves passing your hands to other players when certain cards are played. (This was the second place winner submitted by Sarah Petite.)
     Progressive Uno:  If a draw card is played then the "victim" can play the same type of card thus passing the result on to the next player.  (This was the third place winner submitted by Douglas Temple.)

Well researched, light Ancients rules covering the Greek and Persian Wars, the campaign of Alexander the Great, and the Second Punic War.

Written for individually based miniatures in movement trays. 
Each unit is rated for shooting, melee, morale and special abilities, and move and fight in strict formation. Fighting involves rolling lots of dice.

The rule set includes army lists and historical scenarios.

Players become CTU agents trying to collect clues and prevent terrorist attacks in this thrilling DVD game based on the award-winning 24 television series! Participate in the on-screen games and challenges, and analyze the vital and potentially misleading clues in your quest to thwart terrorism and become the top agent!

Throughout the game, the DVD also acts as a timer, counting down the 24 hours to the terrorist attack that the players are working to prevent. A "virtual CTU office" allows players to analyze data. Future expansions are promised, adding new cases to be solved.

Contents: DVD, game board, game cards, label sheet, player tokens. For 2 or more players, ages 13 and up.

Buy Microbadge - 24 fan


Buy Microbadge - Kiefer Sutherland is a character Jack Bauer plays when he's not saving the world.

An early game from the designer of Hey, That's My Fish!

The game is played on the intersections of a 9×9 grid, each player receives 34 pieces in their color.

A player's turn consists of either
1) Moving 1 piece to a neighboring empty point (optional), followed by placing a new piece on any empty point. (required)

or

2) Taking pieces by jumping over horizontal or vertical lines of their opponent's pieces. If this is possible, this must be done instead of moving/placing pieces via option 1.

Lines with 2 pieces cannot be jumped over, but any other amount can be. The jumping piece must continue jumping until no more jumps are possible. After each jump, the opponent's pieces are captured and removed from the board. If you capture the same number of pieces that your opponent just captured from you on the preceding turn, the pieces are returned to the opponent and not placed in your captured pile.

The game ends when a player cannot make any legal move. Each player gets one point for each captured opponent's piece, plus one point for each opponent's piece on the outside border of the board. Most points wins.

Let's Go Hike is a simple 'spin & move' game set in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area.  Players select from an assortment of forest creature markers such as 'Shirley Squirrel' or 'Matthew Mallard', and race from the Gunflint Trail Ranger Station to the goal: Moon Lake campsite.

An interesting game that verges on being just a toy.  There is a plastic muscle-man, with an empty barbell, and yellow plastic discs as weights.  The game employs a winch system and a turn-crank, by which the players move the Mr. Muscle figure's arms to lift the barbell.

Theme: Weightlifting.  Children's game.
This is a game that lets a person learn about the musical instruments of the West.  It has five different games for various age ranges, ranging from 4 years to adult.

Sylabex is a word-making game, easy to play in which both skill and luck are involved.

The cards all bear a three-letter syllable and a number (which is the points value used in scoring). Any cards when placed beside certain of the other cards forms a complete six letter word, or in some cases will form a nine letter word.

The object of the game is to make words with all the cards in your hand. Other players score the points value of the cards in hand when the round ends, and the winner is the player with the lowest score after the agreed numbers of rounds.

Cleopatra's Caboose: The train game based...in Ancient Egypt?!?

Cleopatra's Caboose is a train game for 3 to 5 players that's based in Ancient Egypt.  Each turn, players bid for the right to utilize a game designer of their choosing which denotes both the turn order and a special ability that can be used that turn.

Players construct tracks, ship fruits to cities that need them, construct buildings for victory points and to improve a city's status, and build pyramids to make a city more prestigious.  Be careful, though; you have a limited amount of money and actions in which to accomplish your goals!  Manage both wisely and become the Emperor of Ancient Egypt!

An exciting game of Travel & Trivia using a factual world map as your playing board.  Players start with airline itineraries & travelers checks and need to be the first player to visit all the cities on their itinerary, collecting the appropriate visa, and return to their country of origin all the while managing their money, navigating detours & diversions.  The first player to collect 10 visas and return to their country of origin is declared the winner.  PLAY:  Players must announce their intended destination before the role of the die which will determine the amount of the fare.   The die role will determine the destination and the cost by displaying full/half or free fares.  If a player rolls divert, transit, geography or general knowledge then they must take the appropriate card from the board and their travel is suspended or diverted depending on the instructions of the card.  Many times players may answer trivia questions about their particular region to allow their flight to continue to their previously stated destination, however, a wrong answer usually keeps the player grounded or relocates them to an undesirable location.   Money is collected by opting not to fly and answering trivia questions or a combination of both.  The Australian game designer recommends this game for ages 12+.

Conflict of Heroes is a fast-paced tactical board game series that follows the development of modern day squad and platoon level tactics, starting with World War II and continuing all the way through modern day Bosnia, Iraq, and Afghanistan. The first game in the series, Awakening the Bear! – Russia 1941-1942, takes you to the eastern front during Operation Barbarossa, the German invasion of Russia. Many consider this time period to be the birth of modern warfare tactics that continue to be used and perfected by today's modern armies.

Conflict of Heroes merges the elegance of streamlined Eurogame rules with deep strategic wargames. The series was designed to create a tense and highly interactive game play experience. You must manage multiple command resources to move, attack, and take other actions with your units. This gives you great flexibility in executing your battle plans, but makes constant caution necessary as unit activations on either side can happen at any time.

Much effort went into distinguishing the units in the game by highlighting their historical strengths and weaknesses. For example, each tank defense rating takes into account relative armor thickness, armor slope deflection percentage, speed, size, targeting mechanics, and crew training. All these factors are represented in an easy to learn target number system.

The included firefights, most of which you can play in about an hour, are designed to depict the pivotal points in a given battle. You can learn enough of the game to play the first scenario in ten minutes thanks to the programmed instruction approach used in the full-color rulebook.

The game also features three- and four-player firefights and optional rules for solitaire play.

Tori (Bird) Shogi is a delightful variant played on a 7×7 board that dates from the late 18th century.  It is thought to have been the first Shogi variant to utilize drops (a mechanic in the modern version of 9×9 Shogi and absent from the original 9×9 Sho Shogi).  Each piece is named after a type of bird.  The royal piece (King) is the Phoenix.  Other pieces include the Swallow (promotes to Wild Goose), Falcon (promotes to Eagle), Crane, Pheasant, and Quail.  The goal of the game is to capture the opposing Phoenix.

Somewhat of an oddity is the fact that a player's two Quail pieces are actually asymmetrical, being designated as the Left Quail and the Right Quail, with their movement capabilities mirrored.  Drops are handled in a manner very similar to modern Shogi.  A third swallow cannot be dropped in a file that contains two others, nor can one be dropped on the last rank, where it would not be able to move.  In addition, a swallow cannot be dropped so as to give immediate mate.

The promotion zone for Swallows and the Falcon consists of the opponent's back two ranks.  Promoted pieces revert to their un-promoted value when they are captured (for purposes of dropping back into play).

A game about horse racing in the American Kentucky Derby / Australian Melbourne Cup.  This is the re-themed,revamped and updated Whitman game that was first put out in 1938 as "Kentucky Derby". This is the revamped and updated Whitman game that was first put out in 1938. The 1961 version features much a fancier board with nicely rendered horses, betting slips and scorecards.

Re-implements:

    Kentucky Derby

Short version of the game is: It plays fast. Usually a battle takes about an hour. It doesn't really matter how the figs are based. Its fairly bloody. Figs are pulled as they are killed. It has the tactics mechanisms built in, so you really only need to worry about what the army you're running is capable of. We strive for historical accuracy, and have a pretty high success rate for duplicating real fights.

* Basic rules, plus a Crusades mini-campaign appendix including 9 armies lists: 62 pages. The Basic Rules are comprehensive, and include siege warfare rules and rules for special weapons such as elephants, chariots and pavises (a large convex shield of European origin used to protect the entire body).
    * Standard 15mm to 40mm frontages used: no rebasing of figurines required. (Although singly-based miniatures work best, multiple-figurine bases work OK in most situations.)
    * Plus 84 additional pages of seven period appendices listing over 160 more armies:
    * Greek & Macedonian Armies
    * Ancient Armies of the Bronze Age
    * Ancient Armies of the Iron Age
    * Ancient Roman and Italian Armies
    * European Dark Ages Armies 500 to 1000 A. D.
    * European Medieval Armies 1000 to 1460 A. D.
    * Chinese, Huns, Mongols and Japanese Armies

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

"You are about to experience the Hawaiian Scene -- living and working in a Pacific paradise while purchasing and developing your favorite Island properties.  A weekend in Maui, snorkeling at Hanauma Bay, and the excitement of Waikiki -- all part of the Hawaiian Scene.  Before you play be prepared to deal with the "Big Five," make peace with labor leaders, influence the Mayor and hire a Kahuna to ensure your success.  Get ready to move fast, play hard, and take risks -- for you're in Hawaii and rolling for high stakes!"
Basically this is a travel variant of Monopoly, with some added mechanics in the form of collecting labor leaders and Kahunas to increase your capital and leverage.  The properties are all Hawaiian businesses circa 1978.

A very concise rule set for Napoleonic naval warfare using 1/3000 scale ship miniatures. The rules are self described as having "loopholes in them, but if you like your games fast, furious and bloody, these rules should work for you".
There is much definition missing from the rules, and they would appeal to gaming friends who do not mind compromising on complexity, and who are not prone too much to arguing over rules.
Damage is recorded on record cards.

From the back of the box: "The era of the old gas lamps is over: the city discovers electricity.
Four power companies are fighting hard for concessions…
HIGH VOLTAGE is a high-strategy game where tactics and interaction are your cutting edge."

Install longer power lines and supply as many neighborhoods as you can with your power company!
Each player acts secretly for one of the four power companies indicated by different colors (red, yellow, green and blue).
Turn after turn the players place the High Voltage cards, so that they form electric lines with the colored segments on the cards.
Whenever two power stations are connected via an electric line, points are assigned to the companies according to the color of the segments (such points are indicated by the colored score markers); the player also receives points, according to the length of the line (such points are indicated by the point tokens).
At the end of the game the players reveal the color of their company and add the points in their possess to the score indicated by their score markers.
The player with the highest score is the winner.

Wargame for Medieval Skirmishes

A painted knight on a hex base take on a man at arms while a couple of archers fling arrows at him. How he swings his sword is factored in the turn and the priority of thrusting before the cut or swings will dictates who will win.

28 pages with some hex pattern "board", charts for orders and abilities and a pull out Summary Sheet help the gameplay.

One small Erratum sheet:

Please note that on the summary sheet 2 for firing and melee, the Melee Procedure contains a typing error:
Line 4 should read "For each hit throw 3 D6 & add attacker's AA."

Retinue

Per Wikipedia:
A retinue (Old French retenue, from retenir also meaning 'to employ', from Latin retenere, hold back, retain) is a body of persons "retained" in the service of a noble or royal personage, a suite (literal French meanings: what follows) of "retainers."

A Retinue is sometimes confused with an entourage, which is the far less stable body of people that followed whether or not they were -or claimed to be- retained or protected by the prominent person they served.

This game, albiet about knights fighting knights, recreates the true method of travel for a knight during the Middle Ages; Never alone!

This skirmish rule set of 42 pages and 2 pull out charts moves from a simple Retinue moving and meeting a group of bandits to Siege warfare. Suitable for a campaign game and weekend warriors, and provides some historical insight on the middle ages (A Knight's Tale" not withstanding)

This is the Card version of the Boardgame "Zatre". The Boardgame is a 2 to 6 players game. The card game is for 2 to 4 players. There are some minor differences in the rules (i.e. no Zatre-fields) so it plays a bit lighter.
An old German game, published in the 40s. An easy one with fighters, bombers, recons, Flak and balloons.The attacker has to fight for the railway station and the defender has to defend it.

"An exciting adventure game"

You're sailing the South Seas with Pippi and the pirates, on an exciting cruise on Pippi's ship Hoppetossa. While visiting a small island, Pippi's feet start to tingle strangely - it's time for a good old brawl and fight after a long sailing! Challenge the five pirates - Pollus, Hot Tin Pan, Oomalat, Dummerkopfen and cook O'Malley - into a dice duel on the gangplank. You'll also need gold coins from the island to bribe them. If you win the pirate you'll get to push him into the sea - but if you lose, it's YOU who'll end up in the drink, and need to swim back to the island for some more coins from Pippi's famous suitcase! Once you get to the ship itself, you need to face ALL the remaining pirates one after the other - unless you're lucky and they're all swimming already, in which case you win an instant victory and get to hoist the flag in Hoppetossa's mast!

A free to print game by Patrice Vernet with the same mechanics of Katmandou.

The game is set in medieval Europe, when most of it was suffering from Plague. Your mission is to eradicate the plague, by controlling  population movements and by using the expertise of special characters (Inquisitor, Physician, Wizard, etc.).

This game is a more spiced up version of Katmandou.

Schmetterling (=butterfly) contains 44 flower tiles, 20 butterfly tiles and 4 tokens for each player. The flower tiles are diagonally separated into 2 halves showing two parts of a flower. Both halves have also a number on it (0-4). The butterfly tiles have numbers from 4 - 24.

Tiles are laid on the table like in dominoes: flower parts must have the same colors are adjacent flower parts. Every time, when a player lays the 4th flower part, a whole flower is completed and that player gets a butterfly card and puts a token on the flower to mark it as his flower.

When the first player has put all his 4 tokens on the table, the tile laying phase ends and the final calculation is done. The numbers on all 4 parts of completed flowers are summarized and if the player possessing it has a butterfly tile with that number, he scores these points. Winner is the player with the most points.

Each player has a set of 20 tiles of different shapes and sizes: 12 x 5-size, 5 x 4-size, 2 x 3-size and 1 x 2-size (88 squares in total). The game is played on a 14x14 board, but five 2x2 spaces are forbidden areas - giving 176 playable spaces.

Each tile has small triangles on all sides. If 2 pieces are laying attached to each other, the triangles form squares on the common sides. These squares are called "towers" and they are important to capture opposing pieces, since they represent the strength of attacking/defending tiles.

Winner of the game is the player who is the first who can lay down all his 20 tiles on the board.

This is nothing more than a book outlining 14 outdoor activities (including several games) that can be played with the included sidewalk chalk (in 6 colors, hence the suggested maximum number of players in this entry).

Some games are no-brainers (Hopscotch, Tic-Tac-Toe) others are a bit unusual (drawing a race track and alternately flicking chalk to draw lines of advancement around the track).

Essentially, it's a structured set of sidewalk chalk.

Tanbark Trail attempts to simulate the exciting world of Holstein show ring competition. The object of the game is to win ribbons and trophies which at the end of the game are converted to points. The player with the most points wins.

At the start of the game, a set number of cattle are auctioned off to the players. During the game, players may purchase more cattle from the sales barn, sell animals back to the sales barn, or trade or purchase from each other.

There are also random event cards drawn during the game that operate much like "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards in Monopoly.

Players move around a board depicting a fairgrounds, at the center of which is the show ring. Any time a player moves his token into the show ring, a competition begins. At this point players must pay an entry fee for each animal they wish to enter in each show class. First, second, and third-place winners are determined by combining die rolls with stats on that animal's card.

The first three rounds of show competition are considered to be State competitions, and the fourth a National competition. After the fourth round, all award ribbons are converted to points, and the winner is determined.

'Starsiege: Rebellion' is a miniatures game set in Sierra/Dynamix's "Starsiege" universe.  Forces present include the Imperials (humans from Earth), Rebels (human colonials on Mars who stumble into advanced alien technology to allow them to rebel), and Cybrids (humanity's long-time enemy...machines who attempted to destroy their creators several times in the past, and each time being beaten back).  At the point of the game, the Cybrids had established a final base around Pluto from which they began a new invasion after the humans started fighting amongst themselves.

There are not many 'scenarios', but the production values are pretty decent - and the game box includes a bucket of miniatures.

The gameplay features unit activation as a combination of laying chits by units and rolling a die, and the combat has some very elegant twists that make it resolve FAST - only 2 dice (one determined by range, the other determined by skill of the firing unit) for are needed to resolve all damage from an attack.  As a result, the game is not very "nitty gritty", like Battletech, but takes a higher-level view of action.  Scenarios played with a dozen units would be over in half an hour, easily, and scenarios with many dozens of units would be playable in an afternoon.

Boxed set includes:

     96-page rulebook 
     29 vehicle data cards
     Master Equipment/Master Weapons Reference Card
     Meeting Engagement Scenario Setup Card
     FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions) Sheet
     80 full-color die-cut counters
     5 full-color die-cut templates
     5 dice (4-, 6-, 8-, 10-, and 12-sided) 
     18 unpainted miniatures


Imperial
- 4 Talon Scout Hercs 
- 4 Obsidian Hover Tanks 
- 1 Minotaur Herc 
Cybrid 
- 4 Seeker Scout Hercs 
- 4 Manta Hover Tanks 
- 1 Shepherd Herc 
- 4 hills (thermal plastic, flocked, from 2" to 7" across)

Buzzword -- The Fastest Word Game Ever!

Players roll out their letter dice, then take turns making words from the upturned letters.  The first player places the first word on a "start square" on the 13x13 board.  All subsequent words must use a letter from a word already on the board, or must extend or alter a word already on the board.

Players have one minute to complete each move.  If time runs out before all the player's letters are in place, the turn is lost.

Play continues until neither player can place any more dice, or until one player has used all of their dice.  That is the end of one round -- three rounds constitute a game.

Before each round, players take turns selecting a "buzzword," which is any four-letter word.  If during play, a player is able to make the buzzword, they get a 25-point bonus.
